To S
r
Tho. Morg
a
Fe
b
23 1590.

page.lettertext:
fol.95r
Belgia. 1591 stilo Ro
m
23 Fe
b
To S
r
Thomas Morgan
Belgia: 1591 Feb
r
S
r
, this cowrse of
S
r
John Norris
in Cassing
e
Companies doth seeme so p
r
judiciall to her
Ma
t
s
vice, that
I have counsayled
e Captaines w
ch
have required my advise
to attend, till her Ma
ty
shall send some further order.
I have also c
r
tified her Hig
nes
of
e great inconvenience
that is like to come of yt, wherby I am in hope to
receave some finall answere w
th
e very first winde.
In
e meane season seing
e countrey doth oppose so earnestly
against yt, & seing also if her Ma
ty
be determined to
draw
e Comp
ies
fro m hence, theyr c
o
tineuing still in garrison
till wee heare somewhat more of her Hig
nes
Intention
is no Impedim
t
to her purpose I could wishe yo
u
to forbeare from any innovation, till yo
u
heare againe
out of
England.
For still they may be cassed, when
her Ma
ty
is resolved to overrule them in this
matter, it may happely bee, that they will licence
the Com
pies
to de
te quietly awaie, wh
r
as oth
r
wise I feare
if
e souldiers bee thus confusedly
dis
charged, both
e Queen
and
e Countrey shall loose
e better half of
e nombers
expected. Moreover mee think
this hastie urging of some
to have
e Comp
ies
cassed is wonderfull strange, considering
that
Berghen
is neer to
Vlisshing,
that when her Ma
t
pleasure shalbee furder notified, & provision made
for
e souldiers embarking, you may p
nt
ly bee able to
convaie
em thether. I have written alredy to
M
r
Kennet
, who I trust will c
o
tinew
e acoustomed lending
so as no occasion of disorder shall be given in theyr
behalf
& so for this p
nt
I bidd yo
u
hartely farewell.
Hage. Feb
r
23 1590./
